hawaiian_text: A lohe 'o 'Ama'u, ho'omākaukau ihola ia i kona mau wa'a kaua he 'umi kumamāwalu, a holo akula i lalo o 'Ewa e kaua me Nāmakaokapāo'o. A hiki 'o 'Ama'u me kona po'e kānaka ma 'Ewa, e noke mai ana 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o i ka luku ā pau loa, 'a'ohe kanaka koe, a make ihola 'o 'Ama'u. Puni a'ela 'o O'ahu nei iā Nāmakaokapāo'o, a laila, ki'i akula ia i kona makuahine a ho'onoho ihola i luna o ka 'āina O'ahu nei.
deepseek-v3-0324-fireworks_translation: When 'Ama'u heard, he prepared his eighteen war canoes and sailed down to 'Ewa to battle Nāmakaokapāo'o. When 'Ama'u and his people arrived at 'Ewa, Nāmakaokapāo'o was fiercely ravaging until none remained—no people survived—and 'Ama'u died. Thus, the island of O'ahu fell under Nāmakaokapāo'o's control, after which he fetched his mother and established her over the land of O'ahu.
deepseek-v3-0324-fireworks_commentary: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>
When 'Ama'u heard, he prepared his eighteen war canoes and sailed down to 'Ewa to battle Nāmakaokapāo'o. When 'Ama'u and his people arrived at 'Ewa, Nāmakaokapāo'o was fiercely ravaging until none remained—no people survived—and 'Ama'u died. Thus, the island of O'ahu fell under Nāmakaokapāo'o's control, after which he fetched his mother and established her over the land of O'ahu.
</translation>

<commentary>
**Paragraph 14:**  
• This passage marks a pivotal battle sequence in the narrative, revealing important cultural and historical themes:  
– **War Canoes & Numerical Symbolism**: 'Ama-'u (Possibly "Drenched/Moist Frond", may reference ferns or resilience) prepares **18 war canoes (ʻumi kumamāwalu)**. The number 18 holds significance:  
   * In Hawaiian numerical symbolism, 8 (walu) often represents abundance or completion, while 10 (ʻumi) signifies totality (Pukui, 1983). The combination (10 + 8) may imply an exhaustive war effort.  
   * War canoes (waʻa kaua) were symbols of chiefly power—each requiring vast resources and labor, indicating 'Amaʻu's high status (cf. Kamakau, 1961).  

– **Battle of ʻEwa & Cultural Allegory**: The devastation in ʻEwa (a fertile region of Oʻahu) reflects:  
   * **Kino Lau (Form Manifestations)**: Nāmaka-okapāoʻo (Eyes-of-the-Pāoʻo-Fish) embodies oceanic destruction (like the pāoʻo fish that burrows violently in sand). His luku (annihilation) mirrors natural forces—akin to tidal waves or lava flows.  
   * **Political Subtext**: The phrase *"ʻaʻohe kanaka koe"* (not one person remained) invokes the ʻōlelo noʻeau (proverb) *"ʻAʻohe wā lihi ʻaʻohe kanaka koʻi"* (Where no boundary remains, no people remain)—critiquing unsustainable conquest (Pukui, 1983: No. 235).  

– **Maternal Authority & Land Stewardship**:  
   * Nāmakaokapāoʻo’s act of fetching his mother Pōkaʻī (Night-of-Kaʻī, possibly "Night-Breaker") to rule Oʻahu underscores:  
      * Matrilineal succession patterns in Hawaiian governance (cf. Sahlins, 1985).  
      * The symbolic transfer of ʻāina (land) stewardship to familial guardians, aligning with the moʻokūʻauhau (genealogical) rights to territory (Goodyear-Kaʻōpua, 2013).  
   * The phrasing *"hoʻonoho ihola i luna o ka ʻāina"* ("established her upon the land") uses the verb ʻnohoʻ (to sit/dwell), invoking royal seating rituals (e.g., the Kahili ceremony).  

• **Allegorical Reading**:  
– The passage may critique pre-contact warfare excesses, with Nāmakaokapāoʻo representing unstoppable change (like Western contact’s upheaval). His victory and subsequent familial governance suggest a return to balanced rule after chaos—a cyclical view of history common in moʻolelo (histories).  
– The mention of **puni** (encircling/subjugation) of Oʻahu reflects the island’s political unification era, possibly allegorizing the rise of the Māʻilikūkahi lineage (Fornander, 1880).  
</commentary>  

This analysis blends linguistic precision (breaking down names like *Nā-maka-o-ka-pāoʻo*), historical context (war canoe logistics), and allegorical layering (natural forces as political metaphors)—all grounded in Hawaiian epistemology.
reference_translation: When 'Ama'u heard about it, he prepared eighteen of his war canoes and went over to 'Ewa to make war with Nāmakaokapāo'o. When 'Ama'u reached 'Ewa with his men, Nāmakaokapāo'o went to work killing them all sparing no one, and that is how 'Ama'u died. All of O'ahu fell to Nāmakaokapāo'o. Then he went and got his mother and set her up as ruler over all of O'ahu.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
